title: Business Live: Theresa May warns on Russia threat - BBC News
summary: may warns on russia at city banquet .

documents.title: brexit bill : what is committee stage ?
text: brexit bill : what is committee stage ?
author: Georgina Pattinson
BBC Parliament Online

documents.title: good night
text: that 's it for this evening , thanks for reading .
do join us when the business live page restarts at 06:00am uk time tomorrow .

documents.title: wall street ekes out gains
text: over on wall street , us stock indexes have finished with modest gains despite a sharp drop in general electric shares .
the industrial giant 's stock fell 7 % , but it was offset by gains for utilities and consumer staples .
the dow jones industrial average rose 0.07 % to 23,439.7 , the s & p 500 gained 0.1 % to 2,584.84 and the nasdaq composite was up 0.1 % to 6,757.60 .

documents.title: may commits to europe protection
text: the prime minister set out the uk 's commitment to protecting europe as she warned of russian aggression , in a speech to uk finance leaders .
theresa may said the uk remained a european nation : `` our history marked by shared experience .
our society shaped by common values .
our economies interdependent .
and our security indivisible . ''

speaking at the lord mayor 's banquet in london , she linked this to brexit , saying that the trade deal she is seeking would underpin britain 's `` shared commitment to open economies and free societies in the face of those who seek to undermine them .
chief among those today , of course , is russia . ''
mrs may went on to speak about russia 's annexation of crimea and accused moscow of `` meddling in elections '' .

documents.title: venezuela debt meeting finished
text: venezuela 's talks with foreign investors , designed to avoid a costly default , are over already , according to reports .
daniel gallas , the bbc 's south america business correspondent , said the meeting reportedly took only 30 minutes .
`` investors who attended the meeting were met with a red carpet .
but no deal or significant change in terms has been announced , '' he said .
author: Daniel Gallas
BBC South America business correspondent

documents.title: brexit : 'a period of great change '
text: `` it 's a period of great change '' - @ twitterid speaking about # brexit at lord mayor of london 's banquet
yes and the 5th biggest economy in the world ca n't afford to educate it 's children probably it has ridicules levels of child poverty
clearly education is needed .
the last part is disgusting , 0.7 % too much of money leaving these shores that should be spent on the uk citizens who financed it .
and if she remains pm she 's going to increase the foreign aid budget .
even more disgusting , but put labour in & it 's probably going up to 17 % .
yeah a change of government
the finance leaders do n't agree with her .
they are moving to other eu cities .
the trade she boasts about is dependent on the eu single market and eu trade deals with the world .
she said before the ref that it would be impossible to replace it .
she was right .
she 's even dressing for brexit back to the seventies in her tank top
from a logic point of view , brexit is utter bollocks .
from any other point of view , it 's utter bollocks too .
they vote will be `` shit sandwich '' or `` really shit sandwich '' , the cheaper option of a parma ham & brie baguette is not allowed .
let 's # stopbrexit and have nice sandwiches .
whichever way cut your sandwich , triangular are straight its not going away , call it a permanent cut .
no longer the 5th , it is the 6th

its a period of great change '' no shit einstein
do we clear a debt or pay a ransom .
official policy , never negotiate if a ransom is demanded .
but we ca n't look after the sick and marginalised in this so called great britain , this woman is living in cloud cuckoo land and the sooner she and her ilk are gone the better for us all
`` we are approaching a defining moment it is a period of great change '' .
yes , your resignation followed by a long-overdue realignment of british politics .
it 's an embarrassing charade .
she 's trapped by the mad old fuckers in the @ twitterid and their idiot arrogance .
still time to grow a spine @ twitterid # fuckbrexit

documents.title: breakingmay warns on russia threat
text: theresa may is addressing city grandees at the annual lord mayor 's banquet in london .
the prime minister 's main message is that a brexit trade deal is needed in the face of security threats from russia .
such a deal will support europe 's commitment to open economies and free societies in the face of russian threats to the international order , she said .
mrs may stressed that a `` comprehensive new economic partnership '' with the eu will `` underpin '' that `` shared commitment '' as moscow seeks to undermine western values .

documents.title: credit suisse fined $ 135m
text: credit suisse has agreed to pay $ 135m to settle allegations in new york that its foreign exchange traders deceived customers and tried to manipulate currency prices .

the traders used chat rooms to share confidential customer information , coordinate trades and try to affect currencies or benchmark rates , the new york state department of financial services ( dfs ) said .

certain credit suisse executives in the bank 's foreign exchange unit deliberately fostered a corrupt culture that failed to implement effective controls in its foreign exchange trading business , '' dfs superintendent maria vullo said .
credit suisse said it was pleased to have reached a settlement with the dfs that `` allows the bank to put this matter behind it '' .
the conduct in question ran from 2008 to 2015 .

documents.title: watch : what do your doodles say about you ?
text: watch : what do your doodles say about you ?

documents.title: will barbie deal go ahead ?
text: us toy maker hasbro is reported to be lining up a bid for barbie-maker mattel , which would create a firm worth about $ 16bn and combine two of the industry 's biggest rivals .
the benefits of a merger `` would be immense '' and unlock hundreds of millions of dollars in savings , says linda bolton weiser , who tracks both companies for financial services firm da davidson .
but other analysts are more reticent .

mattel 's share price has fallen in recent months , which may make it an attractive takeover target but could also make its leaders reluctant to do a deal now , says jaime katz , senior equity analyst for morningstar .
a potential merger could also run into clashes of corporate culture and other processes , ms katz writes in a research note .
`` we caution investors that such speculation [ about a combination ] has fizzled in the past , and a similar fate could occur this go-round , '' she adds .

documents.title: oil ghost town : 'the boom is coming '
text: it 's not only venezuela which was hit hard by the collapse in oil in 2015 and 2016 .

the bbc has visited towns in the us which were geared up for the shale industry , only to see the oil price plunge from over $ 100 a barrel in the middle of 2014 to around $ 30 a barrel at its lowest last year .
oil has since up again , with brent crude currently trading near a two-year high of $ 63 a barrel .
the residents of one of those ghost towns are crossing their fingers that a big boom is on its way .

documents.title: venezuela 's debt problem
text: the venezuelan government is meeting international creditors in caracas later in a bid to renegotiate its foreign debt and avoid a default .
foreign investors hold some $ 60bn worth of bonds issued by the government and state-owned companies .

president nicolas maduro ( has stressed that venezuela will never declare a default , saying the crisis has been caused by a sharp decrease in the international price of oil - venezuela 's main export - and economic sabotage backed by the united states .
but there are plenty of challenges facing maduro 's government - not least the ongoing us sanctions - as it looks to alleviate the country 's economic crisis .

documents.title: us stocks under pressure
text: a quick look at the us markets : the three main stock indexes are in positive territory , but are only showing modest gains .
analysts said that jitters over republican tax cuts and a sharp fall in general electric shares were holding the markets back .
general electric 's shares are down 13 % to their lowest level in five years , after the industrial giant issued a profit warning and announced deep job cuts .
the scores for the us indexes are :

documents.title: coffee firm faces us conservative backlash
text: us conservatives are destroying their keurig coffee machines after the company announced it would stop advertising on a fox news programme .
keurig is among five firms that said they would pull ads from the sean hannity show after the host was accused of going easy on an alleged abuser .
he interviewed alabama republican senate candidate roy moore about claims he assaulted a 14-year-old girl .
the fox news host defended mr moore and cast doubt on the allegations .
read more here .

documents.title: france overtakes us for scottish salmon exports
text: france has overtaken the us to become scottish salmon 's largest export market , according to new figures .
hmrc data released by the scottish salmon producers organisation ( sspo ) showed sales to france were worth nearly £ 45m over the first nine months of this year .
that compared with £ 37m for the united states and £ 14m for china .
overall , salmon sales were valued at £ 483m , a 56 % increase on the same period last year .
read more here .

documents.title: google faces us competition investigation
text: missouri 's top prosecutor plans to investigate google 's business practices , in another sign that the regulatory stance toward internet giants may be shifting in the us .
missouri attorney general josh hawley said he will examine possible violation of consumer and antitrust laws .
he said he is interested in google 's collection of user data , alleged scraping of information from other websites and alleged manipulation of search results .
when a company has access to as much consumer information as google does , it 's my duty to ensure they are using it appropriately , '' hawley said .
i will not let missouri consumers and businesses be exploited by industry giants . ''
in june , european union authorities slapped google with a record fine , a ruling the search giant has appealed .
author: Natalie Sherman
New York business reporter

documents.title: mps 'will get time to debate ' brexit deal
text: mps 'will get time to debate ' brexit deal

documents.title: ftse winners and losers
text: top gainers on the ftse 100 were carnival up 83p to 4,947p , astrazeneca up 60p to 4,930p , diageo up 21p to 2,580.5p , and royal dutch shell 's 'b ' shares up 20p to 2,477.5p .
on the downside , the biggest fallers were babcock international group - down 59.5p to 753p , coca-cola hbc down 115p to 2 , 470p , nmc health down 118p to 2,800p , and bae systems down 19p to 537p .

documents.title: supersonic ambitions
text: business reporter russell hotten met the man trying to build the next-generation concorde .
former amazon executive blake scholl is at the dubai airshow trying to woo investors and middle east airlines to back his ambition to once again make breaking the sound barrier commercially viable .
it 's an idea that a few years ago might have been dismissed with a polite `` good luck '' , but one which is now taking on serious shape , mr scholl says .
read more here .

documents.title: 'talk of the city '
text: the political uncertainty surrounding the prime minister is the `` talk of the city '' , according to cmc markets analyst david madden .
sterling - which is down 0.7 % against the dollar and hovering around the $ 1.31 mark - is `` feeling the pressure , just like theresa may '' , he says .
`` mrs may has had a tough six months , and it appears some conservative mp 's are running low on patience , '' he adds .
the government is also under pressure to meet a two-week deadline set on friday by the eu 's chief brexit negotiator michel barnier for a deal on exit terms .
`` clearly the brexit negotiations are at a crucial juncture , '' says rabobank analyst jane foley .
`` however , without a majority may 's leadership has been weakened and she appears unable to rally her cabinet behind her . ''

documents.title: if at first you do n't succeed
text: hock tan , the boss of chip maker broadcom , is n't taking no for an answer just yet .
his $ 103bn bid for rival chip maker qualcomm was turned down earlier for `` drastically '' undervaluing the us company .
but mr tan has responded by saying he 's `` encouraged '' by the reaction of qualcomm 's shareholders to last week 's offer , and remains `` fully committed '' to the deal .
even before lodging the bid , mr tan had moved into the spotlight .
the 65 year-old met with donald trump in the oval office earlier this month ( to announce his firm would shift its legal base from singapore to the us .

documents.title: pay rise for teachers ?
text: a powerful voice from the conservative back benches has added her weight to those who say that the public sector pay cap , in force since 2013 following a three-year freeze , should be lifted .

nicky morgan , the former education secretary and now chairwoman of the treasury select committee , said that although she did not back a `` blanket '' lifting of the limit , the case for teachers was a powerful one .
ms morgan said there would be a lot of talk in the budget about low productivity , and that one way to improve productivity would be to ensure people are getting the best education .

`` so , inevitably , i would argue , yes , as a former education secretary , if i was still doing the job , i 'd be having a pretty fierce argument with the treasury about saying : 'look , the public sector pay cap should be lifted , if not for everybody in the schools and education profession , then at least for those who actually we 're finding it hardest to recruit and retain , ' '' she said .
read more from kamal 's blog here .
author: Kamal Ahmed
Economics editor

documents.title: 'pick up the pace '
text: carolyn fairbairn , the cbi chief , says businesses in both the uk and europe want faster brexit negotiations to provide the certainty needed to protect jobs .
the cbi and european business bodies met with prime minister theresa may today in downing street for a meeting on brexit .

documents.title: ftse finishes lower
text: the uk 's ftse 100 of leading shares gave up its early gains to finish 0.2 % lower at 7,415.18 .
it comes amid wider losses on european stock markets .
germany 's dax dropped 0.4 % while france 's cac 40 fell 0.7 % .
analysts suggested the decline in sterling - which benefits ftse 100 firms with earnings abroad - had cushioned the uk index from a sharper fall .

documents.title: sterling pares losses
text: the pound has continued to claw back some of the losses it saw this morning .
it is now back above $ 1.31 - only just - and is trading at $ 1.3108 .
that is still a fall of 0.67 % on the day .
nandini ramakrishnan , a global market strategist at jp morgan asset management , said the pound is likely to see continued volatility .
`` do we expect the weakness in the pound to reverse ?
not really , it 's going to be a pound that moves up and down throughout the course of the next few months , really , '' she told the bbc .

documents.title: barclays savers miss full rate rise
text: barclays has become the latest bank to fail to pass on the full rise in base rates to many of its savers .
it comes after royal bank of scotland , natwest and tesco bank announced on friday that their savings rates would rise by 0.2 % or less .
only about 20 providers out of 150 have so far passed on the full 0.25 % rate rise to savers , despite pleas from number 10 and the bank of england .
barclays children 's instant saver and help to buy isa to get the full 0.25 % extra , but instant cash isa up by 0.15 %
barclays customers with money in the everyday saver account paying just 0.05 % will get 0.15 % extra from december , not the full 0.25 % base rate rise

documents.title: eu 'does n't get clearing ' - deutsche bossnewsnight business editor tweets
text: eu 'does n't get clearing ' - deutsche bossnewsnight business editor tweets

documents.title: in a barbie world
text: for decades , barbie-maker mattel and monopoly-manufactuer hasbro have been bitter rivals , competing ferociously to create the must-have toys .
but hasbro is now interested in bringing the two companies together in a $ 16bn merger that would shake up the toy industry , according to media reports .
investors in both companies like the sound of the potential deal , which would unite hasbro 's my little pony , star wars and nerf brands with mattel 's barbie dolls and hot wheels toys .

shares in mattel are up 19 % today and hasbro is 7 % higher , with analysts suggesting a deal would help the two firms compete with all the other games , apps and consoles jostling for kids ' attention .

documents.title: wall street off to cautious start
text: the momentum in us stocks ground to a halt last week , with the s & p 500 and dow jones indexes finishing lower for the first time in two months .
the falls came largely amid uncertainty about the passage of republican tax cuts .
it 's a similar story in the first hour of trading on wall street , with the main us stock indexes struggling to make meaningful gains .
the dow jones is up by 0.08 % to 23,441 and the s & p 500 is just 0.04 % higher at 2,583 .
the nasdaq is down 0.04 % to 6,748 .

documents.title: pound still below $ 1.31
text: the pound has pared some of it losses against the dollar - but it 's still trading below $ 1.31 , a fall of 0.75 % .
against the euro , it 's down 0.73 % to €1.12250 .
analysts suggested the fall was linked to uncertainty about the brexit talks and theresa may 's grip on government .

`` the political news over the weekend shows that her [ may 's ] position is coming under increasing pressure and currency markets are reacting to that , '' said alvin tan , an fx strategist at societe generale in london .

documents.title: bitcoin rises by $ 1,000
text: we write a lot about currency movements on the business live page , but i doubt we 've seen many as sharp as today 's surge in the price of bitcoin .
the cryptocurrency - which is much more volatile than traditional currencies - has recovered more than $ 1,000 after losing almost a third of its value at the end of last week .
it 's currently trading at about $ 6,520 as traders bought back into the digital coin , having fallen as low as $ 5,555 on sunday , according to reuters .
the digital coin dropped after a planned software upgrade , which could have split the cryptocurrency in a so-called `` fork '' , was abandoned last week .

documents.title: in the doghouse ?
text: business leaders have warned against a `` no deal '' brexit , often seen as a scenario where the uk and eu fail to reach an agreement before formal talks finish in 2019 .
it 's not just companies that could be affected , but pets too , according to the eu 's chief brexit negotiator .
reality check has looked at what brexit might mean for our furry friends
would `` no deal '' be a problem for dogs , cats , or indeed ferrets ?
so they want to hold our pets to ransom now ? !
how desperately pathetic ! !
its not ransom , there is currently a system run by the eu , if we leave we ca n't use their system unless we pay towards the maintainance of the system .

i see by your timeline that you hope to stop brexit all i can say to you is that you need to accept that we are leaving the eu you will be more contented within yourself without this false hope as for the pet thing you and i both know that its just eu having a tantrum
i do not have to accept it , i could not be content if i did .
the eu does not have tantrums .
for pets there is a system in place which will disapear if we leave its a fact .
a new system will be needed , like so many things .
ok carry on with your head in the sand if you wish good evening and hope you see sense soon
a differance of opinion but polite which is nice .

now threatening to restrict entry to pets on holiday and the landing rights to tourist aircraft and the millions of euro revenues spent in eu countries by uk nationals ?
is this negotiation ?
there is currently a system run by the eu , if we leave we ca n't use their system unless we pay towards the maintainance of the system .
its called being fair .
there is currently a system run by the eu , if we leave we ca n't use their system unless we pay towards the maintainance of the system .
its called being fair .
seem to remember the problem was 6 mths quarantine at the uk side for fear of importing rabies from europe .
both my cat and my dog are staunch remainers .
it 's literally the only thing they agree on .
it works both ways guys - what the hell are the bbc going to do after brexit oh i have got it do some proper investigative reporting naaaaaa
to all rose people who were too young , britain managed to do very well on it 's own before we became members of the e.u . !
new opportunity brexiting leads to more petsitting

my cat is devastated ! !

documents.title: may : business can 'thrive ' post-brexit
text: as we reported earlier , european and uk business leaders have told the prime minister of their brexit concerns at a meeting in downing street .
representatives from groups including the cbi and businesseurope pressed for a transitional deal that preserves the status quo after the uk leaves the eu .
theresa may has said the uk must do everything it can to ensure british and eu businesses `` thrive side-by-side '' after brexit .
as we leave the eu , we must do all we can to ensure that uk and eu businesses continue to thrive side-by-side .
that 's why it was so important to speak to european business leaders in downing street this morning :
eu businesses will certainly thrive because they have all the advantages of the single market .
we 'll be competing against them .
having no tariffs on goods to the uk will be bring the prices down , the ordinary people are the customers , so it is a victory in that sense .
it will allow us more disposable income
tariffs do n't affect costs/prices as much as the regulatory barriers mentioned above .
so you can comfirm that the price of food , clothes and footwear will increase in price if we left on wto rules and removed tariffs ?
given that the environment sec has impact assessments on it but is n't releasing them .
given that much of our food comes from eu and brexit increases regulatory costs .
given that the pound has fallen so the cost of importing has risen .
given that food prices have already risen yes
i admire your passion towards this , but out of interest , do you hope that you 'll be wrong and for the good of the uk , brexit is a success ?
if brexit is n't stopped , then sure i hope we make the best of it .
but i 'm not looking at uncertainty .
law was my degree , eu law was my specialisation .
i 've spent the past 3 years working in eu affairs .
brexit is n't an `` uncertainty '' from where i 'm standing .
it 's certain harm ,
femi you 're boring .
the uk voted to leave .
brexit is n't going to be stopped .
nobody who 's negotiating is going to release a report on what the outcomes of said negotiations are going to effect , it would be stupid .
plus , you get that eu businesses are in competition as well right ?
shame there are no non-white uk politicians or business leaders present .
# diversity
find an examples of non white business leaders , look up who these people are and then present a case as to why the non white leaders should be there instead .
then you 'll have a case .
until then diversity for the sake of diversity is n't a reason .
credit suisse with a hq in london
yup .
he 's a stud and came to mind but not in the eu .
reckon he had a massive say in how eu passporting issue gets sorted .
big presence in the city .
true enough .
he probably laughed and looked at his schedule .
this british born tweeter is bored now that the obvious has been stated .
may was the pm who screamed for a fairer britain for us brits with a different skin colour too .
she did n't send # racistvans to target aussie/us/nz/sa/canadian overstayers after all .
i know a canadian who was removed for a year .
are they smiling because you 've assured them they do n't need to pay any taxes ?
the eu 's anti tax avoidance directive that comes into force on 1st january 2019 is the main reason why the brexit tories want to leave in such a hurry .
absolutely .
i did n't see that one on the side of the big red bus must have missed that one !
less tax for business more companies , more companies more employment , more people with money more money being spent in the economy .
i get your point , and well made .
but this thread is more about tax avoidance where the wealthy hide their cash offshore .
in this way , trickle-down economics does not function for any country 's benefit , only for super-wealthy individuals , unfortunately .
totally with you .
bt maybe see it frm another angle .

are they better off than us ?
living in paris will make you more well off or better than living in london ?
i do n't think so
i would suggest that living in paris is much better than living in london .
i would suggest both cities are now shote holes

documents.title: lyft off
text: taxi-hailing app lyft - seen as one of uber 's biggest rivals in the us - is making its first move into an international market .
the san francisco start-up is launching in toronto , canada , and in a burst of californian enthusiasm says it 's `` super pumped '' to be taking its business to `` our close friends up north '' .
lyft , which offers a similar service to uber , raised $ 1bn last month from google 's parent company alphabet .
when it launched in 2012 , cars using lyft had pink moustaches on the front bumper , although those have recently been replaced by a psychedelic dashboard display (
lyft is yet to launch in the uk - although it was recently reported that the company held talks with london transport officials in the past year .

documents.title: breakingge to axe thousands of jobs
text: as well as cutting the dividend , ge plans to slash thousands of jobs to reduce costs , while shrinking its business to focus on aviation , healthcare and energy .
the maker of jet engines and power turbines , whose market value has fallen by more than $ 100bn this year , will sell parts of its transportation and electricity businesses .
the industrial conglomerate is selling off more than $ 20bn in assets , and also will exit the oil services business baker hughes , in which it has a controlling stake .

documents.title: breaking $ 103bn chip merger short-circuits
text: mobile chipmaker qualcomm has rejected rival broadcom 's $ 103bn takeover bid , saying the offer `` dramatically '' undervalued the us company .

`` after a comprehensive review the board has concluded that broadcom 's proposal dramatically undervalues qualcomm and comes with significant regulatory uncertainty , '' said qualcomm 's presiding director tom horton .
broadcom made its unsolicited bid last week in its efforts to become the dominant supplier of chips used in the 1.5 billion smartphones expected to be sold around the world this year .

documents.title: oxfam goes digital
text: oxfam says that uk high streets are becoming so crowded due to fewer shops closing down that it is now looking to sell donations online instead .

`` people can look at their convenience , they can get a really good search in and we get more money for tackling disasters and helping people live better lives , '' mark goldring , chief executive of oxfam gb told the today programme .
the move could help to reduce overheads in its charity shops .
at the moment , 82p out of every pound raised is spent directly on oxfam programmes .
the other 10p goes on paying store rent and staff , while the remaining 8p is spent on raising funds .

documents.title: ineos goes swiss
text: british chemical giant ineos is set to buy lausanne-sport , which by some measure is europe 's oldest football club .
the football team has won the swiss league seven times , but not since 1965 , and the swiss cup nine times - slightly more recently in 1999 .
ineos snapped up motorcycle wear firm belstaff last month after it was put up for sale by jab holdings .

documents.title: inflation 'likely to remain above target '
text: uk inflation is likely to remain above target for the next few years , according to the bank of england 's chief economist andy haldane .

`` price rises across the whole economy are currently running well above the 2 % inflation target and are expected to remain above-target for the next few years , '' mr haldane wrote in a blog post about a townhall visit to greater manchester .
`` the rise in inflation through this year has already generated such a squeeze on many households ' purchasing power .
`` this is not something the bank , or anyone else , should wish to see continuing for years to come - hence the nudge up in interest rates . ''

documents.title: from warm words to action
text: cbi chief carolyn fairbairn gave her take on what needs to happen next to gain progress on brexit talks following a meeting between business groups and theresa may .
a transition period reflecting the current arrangements remains the priority on both sides of the channel .
while businesses welcomed the prime minister 's florence speech , we now need to move beyond warm words if jobs , investment and living standards are to be protected .

documents.title: a guide to the eu withdrawal bill
text: a guide to the eu withdrawal bill

documents.title: brexit talks need momentum
text: so business groups have now met with prime minister theresa may and here 's what they have to say :
business is extremely concerned with the slow pace of negotiations and the lack of progress only one month before the decisive december european council .

business aims to avoid a cliff edge and therefore asks for a status quo - like '' transitional arrangement with the uk staying in the customs union and the single market as this will best provide citizens and businesses with greater certainty .

in order to achieve this goal , we urge the uk government to make good on its florence commitments by providing concrete proposals on the three issues critical for talks to move to the next phase including citizens ' rights , the situation of ireland and the financial settlement .
equally , the eu should look constructively on these proposals once received .
gaining momentum as we head into the new year will provide companies with the confidence they need to continue contributing to prosperity right across europe in these uncertain times . ''

documents.title: london stock markets fall
text: the ftse 100 has now reversed earlier gains and is trading 14.20 points lower at 7,418.79
astrazeneca is still leading the risers but the pharmaceutical group has pared back its share price rise to 1.72 % to £ 49.54 .
defence company babcock international is now monday 's biggest faller and is down 6.5 % at 759.50p .
meanwhile , the ftse 250 has plunged 215.74 points to 19,805.11 .
shares in ultra electronics are down 20.69 % at £ 12.11 .

documents.title: nisa members will still 'enjoy independence '
text: as part of the co-op group 's offer for nisa , it will take on £ 105m of the convenience store company 's debt .
also nisa shareholders - or members - will receive an equal initial payment , a deferred share payment payable over 3 years , as well as additional rebates payable over 4 years .

nisa said : `` members will still enjoy the independence to operate their stores as they wish , and will be able to remain part of a member-owned organisation within the growing uk convenience retail sector . ''

documents.title: nisa hails co-op deal
text: peter hartley , chairman of nisa , says : `` we are delighted that our members have chosen in such significant numbers to vote in favour of co-op 's offer .
`` we as a board are firm in our belief that a combination with the co-op is in the best interests of nisa 's members .
`` the convenience store environment is changing rapidly , and is unrecognisable from that which existed when nisa was founded more than 40 years ago .
co-op will add buying power and product range to our offering , while respecting our culture of independence . ''

documents.title: breakingnisa members vote for co-op takeover
text: nisa retail has announced that its members have voted in favour of the co-op group 's offer to buy the wholesaler and convenience store business for up to £ 137.5m .
it said members voted 75.79 % in favour and 24.21 % against the co-op 's offer .

documents.title: new ge boss takes axe to dividend
text: general electric 's new-ish chief executive john flannery , who took over the helm of the us conglomerate from jeff immelt , is shaking things up and is cutting the company 's quarterly dividend in half .
this is only the third time in ge 's 125-year history that the payment to shareholders has been cut .
mr flannery is expected to announce other cost-saving measures .

meanwhile , a story that may have slipped under radar but deserves dusting-off is a wall street journal report from last month detailing how mr immelt liked to have an empty business jet follow his ge-owned plant on work trips around the world .
mr immelt requested the extra wings just in case the plane he was flying in suffered any mechanical faults .

documents.title: gone in a puffa smoke
text: moncler to push puffas off the catwalk

documents.title: this week : uk economy figures released
text: it is an important week for economics .
the consumer price index measure of inflation for october will be released on tuesday .
in september , it rose to 3 % , far above the bank of england 's 2 % target and is forecast to increase further still to 3.2 % .

on wednesday , the office for national statistics will reveal if wages are closing the gap with inflation or are we being squeezed by stagnant pay growth when it publishes employment figures at 9.30am .

documents.title: sterling struggles to claw back ground
text: the pound seems to be holding steady on the dollar at $ 1.30890 , down 0.77 % .
sterling has extended its decline against the euro and is now off 0.65 % at €1.12350 .

currency traders are spooked by the prospect of political instability following a report in the sunday times which claims that 40 mps have agreed to sign a letter of no confidence in prime minister theresa may .
there are also concerns that a preliminary brexit deal will not be signed by december while the eu withdrawal bill returns to the commons on tuesday .

documents.title: working from 8-4
text: it does n't have quite the same ring as dolly parton 's theme tune to the classic 1980 film but apparently working brits would prefer their eight-hour day to start and finish before the traditional 9 to 5 working day .
a new survey by yougov has found quarter of the 1,965 working adults interviewed said that they would prefer to work from 8am to 4pm .
however , younger people ( aged 18-24 ) and people living in london would prefer to start after 9am , in contrast with the rest of the country .

documents.title: a balancing act over brexit
text: prime minister theresa may is walking a tightrope over the uk 's exit from the european union .
mr goodwin tells bbc business live : `` some of theresa may 's proposals were perhaps not popular among business , but they have been welcomed by voters .

`` if you look at the electorate , they 're still very concerned about an economy focused on london and the elite , they 're very concerned that globalisation does n't feel to be very fair and resources are not being evenly distributed , but also , it 's those concerns over what is our new migration policy going to be ?
`` business says you ca n't just slash migration , but voters say they really want to see much lower levels of migration into the uk . ''
author: BBC Business Live

documents.title: watchdog warns on icos
text: the risks of initial coin offerings ( icos ) , which let businesses raise funds by offering their own digital currencies , have been highlighted by the european securities and markets authority .

the watchdog said the offerings are `` very risky and highly speculative investments '' because the price of the cryptocurrencies is `` extremely volatile '' , and investors may not be able to redeem them for a prolonged period .
the authority also has concerns that some icos fall outside eu laws and regulations , or are not complying with relevant eu legislation .
in september , chinese regulators banned icos outright , calling them `` illegal '' and demanding investors be refunded .

documents.title: sterling under pressure
text: more volatility with the pound is expected this week , says neil wilson at etx capital .
`` with the eu preparing for talks to collapse , the stakes are getting higher .
britain has less than two weeks to come up with answers for the eu or we face a potential no-deal scenario , '' he said .
`` if the market decides the uk can not meet the eu 's demands in time it could send the pound sharply lower , perhaps to $ 1.25 or below before the deadline is reached .
as we approach barnier 's deadline implied volatility levels may rise further and this may see sterling squeezed . ''

documents.title: nothing artificial about this investment
text: technology correspondent rory cellan-jones tweets :
earlier this year the world service interviewed graphcore 's chief executive nigel toon :
this content only works in the uk .
big boost for uk ai - top silicon valley venture capital firm sequoia invests $ 50m in bristol-based graphcore , which makes ai chips
this is great news for tech .
would n't it be great to see uk vc companies invest in uk ai .

documents.title: opec : market is 'rebalancing '
text: still on oil , the opec secretary-general says the rebalancing of the oil market is gathering pace , as stockpiles fall but demand for remains robust .
mohammad barkindo tells an energy industry conference he is confident that both the oil industry and the global economy are benefitting from the deal to cut output among major producers .

documents.title: oil optimism
text: oil prices have remained relatively steady on monday , with brent crude holding above $ 63 a barrel .
prices rose last week given the events in saudi arabia , and neil dwane , global strategist at allianz global , reckons it has further to go .

`` fundamentally , we think the oil markets need about $ 70- $ 75 a barrel to encourage investment , because global oil demand is still rising fairly solidly , it 's about a million barrels of oil per day , per year .

`` the reason it [ the price ] is still so low is that there 's this tremendous optimism around us shale , which has delivered nearly two thirds of all the incremental volume growth we 've seen in the last two or three years .
`` we think that optimism is misplaced .
we 're already seeing tremendous cost inflation inside their business because the rigs are becoming more expensive to run . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: airbus jilted ?
text: talk about overpromising and under delivering .
before the dubai airshow got underway on sunday , the media was tipped off to expect an announcement that airline emirates was buying more a380 superjumbo jets from airbus .
this was not just any multi-billion-dollar order , but a lifeline for an aircraft programme that is fast running out of buyers .
to add to the drama , emirates was also buying boeing aircraft and wanted to bring the us company and its arch rival airbus together for a joint press conference .
that , said a boeing executive , would have been a unique event ; never happened in my lifetime '' .
but five minutes before the press conference began , the airbus entourage melted away from the room , leaving the middle east 's largest carrier to unveil just a $ 15bn order for boeing aircraft .
what happened ?
one source says that after an all-night negotiating session to finalise a deal , emirates presented airbus with last-minute demands .
it 's hardball stuff , '' he says .
emirates know how urgently airbus needs to shift some more a380s .
they 've [ emirates ] just turned the screw .
boeing will be talking about this moment for years . ''
author: Russell Hotten
BBC Business Reporter, Dubai Airshow

documents.title: bitcoin price plunges
text: the price of bitcoin on monday has plunged 29 % , falling to as low as $ 5,605 ( £ 4,287 ) .
the cryptocurrency hit a record high of $ 7,800 last wednesday .

documents.title: get on with it
text: the businesses from 11 countries who are meeting with prime minister theresa may on monday to discuss brexit have one key message .
`` they want more detail on the transitional deal , they 're saying to the pm essentially , 'get on with it .
brussels , let 's really hammer home this new trade relationship ' , '' says matthew goodwin , senior fellow at chatham house .
author: BBC Business Live

documents.title: japan stocks extend losing streak
text: tokyo shares led declines in a mostly downbeat start to the trading week in asia .
real estate companies were among the biggest losers , dragging the benchmark nikkei index down 1.3 % , or 300 points , to close at 22,380.99 , in the fourth day of falls .
elsewhere in asia , south korea 's kospi index shed 12.60 points , or 0.5 % to end at 2,530.35 .
australia 's s & p/asx 200 index fell 7.6 points , or 0.1 % , to 6,021.8 .
hong kong 's hang seng index bucked the trend , adding 0.2 % , or 61.26 points , to close at 29,182.18 .

documents.title: ftse indexes diverge
text: astrazeneca is leading the ftse 100 risers on monday morning .
shares in the pharmaceuticals giant are up 2.2 % at £ 49.81 .
it is followed by precious metals miner fresnillo which is ahead 1.46 % at £ 13.17 .
bottling group coca-cola hbc is leading the ftse 100 fallers , down 4.6 % at £ 24.66 .
the main blue chip index remains ahead , up 20.34 points at 7,453.33 .
the ftse 250 has reversed earlier gains and is now down 58.91 points at 19,961.94 .
ultra electronics is the biggest faller following a warning on full-year figures and the departure of its chief executive .
its shares are off 19.97 % at £ 12.22 .

documents.title: innogy takes £ 427m hit on npower value
text: german energy giant innogy has cut the value of its uk energy business npower by €480m ( £ 427m ) , amid a `` difficult situation '' in the uk market .
last week , innogy confirmed it planned to merge npower with sse 's uk energy supply business to form a new company .
innogy 's announced the writedown in npower 's value as it reported results for the nine months to september .
it said competition in the uk retail business remained `` very tough and pressure on margins is very high '' .
read more here .

documents.title: big risks , big rewardsbbc breakfast presenter sean farrington tweets
text: boss of bet365 , denise coates was paid more than £ 200m last year @ cbicarolyn told @ twitterid want the future googles and facebooks to be in the uk .
encouraging people to really take risks if that involves some very big rewards , i think that can be entirely appropriate ''
well twisted !
yes so you end up with more and they end up with less ?
do you actually care ?
no !
so what ? ?

documents.title: time to go wto ?
text: while many european business leaders are concerned that time is running out for a transitional trade deal , others feel theresa may should not be focusing on this .

`` there 's no point discussing this for much longer on this current basis , '' british property developer richard tice , co-founder of leave.uk and co-chair of leave means leave told the today programme .

`` time is very short , and candidly , if we have n't got confirmation from the eu that they are willing to start negotiating about trade , if we have n't got a deal on an implementation period agreed by the end of march with a clear sense of direction that a free trade deal is going to be reached

`` then actually , we would be better to give certainty to everybody that we 're going to do a different type of deal - go to the world trade organisation ( wto ) - which is of course what most great trading nations around the world operate under . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: is technology listening to us ?
text: gchq is concerned that the beleaguered russian antivirus software kaspersky labs could be being used by foreign governments to spy on us .
do you think you 're being spied on ?
tweet # bbcbizlive to have your say .
british authorities say kaspersky anti-virus software could allow foreign governments to spy on you
i remember when kaspersky came out , everyone everywhere said it was the best protection for pc 's most folks i know used that antivirus software .
so the answer is yup , probably !
everysingle computer software like anti viruses is used to spy by agencies in whole world .
tell us something new .
viruses and anti viruses built by same companies its old story , companies like napster etc
do n't the british government spy on its people and moreover never trust an anti virus software 100 % .
the world will know what 's actually going on and not have to rely on bbc for it biased news .
i had concerns regarding kaspersky and russian authorities many years ago .
refused to deploy kaspersky products on my systems due to this .
well as this is a russian developed programme it is quite likely
the british authority forget to tell us the cia wrote a software to mimic kaspersky anti virus
oh cia i do n't know how much e computer bug in cia .
i have felt that way for a long time .
no i do n't feel i am being spied on .
why waste their time .
but i can not believe why anyone who has a business would use them
i think i might be being spied on .
i bought a poppy and soon everyone was wearing a poppy how did they know ?
best reply ever .
people so serious
thank you
why not just say russia instead of foreign govt ? ?
bbc - propaganda tv .
when govts like british and usa are biggest and worst in terms of spying on their citizens , such news ( read propaganda ) is hilarious
why all that anger.every country spies including yours
not angry just putting the facts across.propaganda against russia by brit and us media is well known .
no one is saint here but one sided stories , baseless propaganda shown in the garb of news is repelling and that 's what i pointed out .
ok abuja .
have a good day .
i didnt use my software sold with my computer .
tried to download it but had problems , than found out came from russia .
never used it .
that is ���ℎ a bullshit .
fud in its purest form .
yeah , but i also know the intrusive way the kapersky applications install on machines , so take it as you will .
they will be so disappointed if they have spy on me

documents.title: sterling slides
text: the pound is now 0.74 % lower on the dollar at $ 1.30930 over reports at the weekend in the sunday times that 40 mps have agreed to sign a letter of no confidence in theresa may as the prime minister faces a crunch meeting .
sterling is trading 0.52 % lower on the euro at €1.12490 .

documents.title: ultra shares tumble
text: shares in ultra electronics have plunged by 21.22 % to £ 12.03 after announcing that its full-year revenue will hit £ 770m and organic sales will fall by 4 % because of the ministry of defence `` pausing , cancelling or delaying numerous programmes '' .
last week , it announced that after a `` period of reflection '' by its non-executives , chief executive rakesh sharma was stepping down .

documents.title: deaths flat , says dignity
text: funerals are big business - and competitive .
dignity plc has reported a 6 % rise in sales to £ 243.9m in the third quarter while underlying profit is ahead 5 % at £ 79.4m .
however , it says : `` the number of deaths in the third quarter was flat on the previous year . ''

dignity says that while other areas of the company are doing well , such as its crematorium operation , `` we continue to see increasing price competition and new competitors in our funeral business '' .

documents.title: london stock markets open higher
text: the ftse 100 has made a positive start to the week .
the blue chip stock index is up 29.88 points at 7,462.87 .
the ftse 250 is also ahead , up 23.84 points at 20,044.69 .

documents.title: housing is key
text: laura gardiner , senior research and policy analyst at the resolution foundation , agrees that housing is key to solving the problem of intergenerational inequality .

she says : `` what we need to realise is that if we are going to get the levels of supply we need , history tells us that we need more government spending in this area whether that be supporting private development or funding affordable building .

`` that 's why we had communities secretary sajid javid mentioning very big numbers in the press in the run up to the budget and that spending needs to come through if we 're going to meet his bold claims of around 300,000 new homes a year over the next few years .
`` that 's more than double what we 're doing at the moment . ''
author: BBC Radio 5 live

documents.title: uber moves closer to softbank deal
text: uber has struck a deal that could lead to a huge investment by a consortium led by japanese conglomerate softbank and san francisco group dragoneer .
the size of the potential investment has not been disclosed , but reports say it could be up to $ 10bn ( £ 7.6bn ) .
the taxi-hailing company said the money would fuel uber 's expansion and investments in technology .
read more here

documents.title: the pound falls on the dollar
text: sterling has made an inaus start to trading as speculation re-surfaced about the future of theresa may 's premiership .
overnight it fell 0.7 % to $ 1.3103 .

documents.title: a technology problem
text: the cbi is concerned that there is a `` curious '' productivity inequality among uk firms - many are missing out when it comes to adopting technologies .
the cbi 's ms fairbairn says : `` we have the best of the best at one end , and then we have a long tail of low-productivity firms at the other end , bigger than in many other parts of europe .

`` one of the biggest reasons is we 're one of the slowest adopters of technologies , and we 're not talking about ai [ artificial intelligence ] here - we 're talking about websites , mobile technologies , lean practices .

`` and if we could just get that long tail of lower productivity firms up to the average , the impact on the economy we think could be up to £ 100bn a year and a reduction in inequality , because differences in productivity in firms creates differences in pay for people . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: ladbrokes sales improve
text: bookmaking giant ladbrokes coral has announced improved trading in the four months to 29 october though like-for-like sales remain in negative territory .
like-for-like retail revenue fell by 1 % while its over the counter stakes declined by 5 % .
this compares to a 9 % fall in the second quarter and an 8 % declined over the first half .
total group revenue rose by 3 % in the most recent period .

documents.title: demand for housing is strong , says taylor wimpey
text: housebuilder taylor wimpey has had a strong performance in its second half , supported by demand for new housing .
however , it reported a slight dip in its order book of 8,751 homes valued at £ 2.2bn .
this compared to last year 's order book of 8,981 houses worth £ 2.3bn .

taylor wimpey chief executive pete redfern said : `` while we are alert to potential political and economic risks , demand for new housing remains high across the uk and market conditions are favourable .
`` notwithstanding the recent small increase in the base rate , we have continued to see stability in trading patterns .
`` looking ahead , we are on track to meet our full year expectations and deliver further growth and performance improvement in 2018 . ''

documents.title: r & d will help productivity
text: the cbi has said that uk firms are falling behind by failing behind their competitors in adopting even tried-and-tested technologies .
but how can we fix this problem ?

neil dwane , global strategist at allianz global , says that the government has to change how it approaches research and development ( r & d ) , pointing to the example of a non-stick frying pan being an unlikely product that came out of nasa 's research into the space race in the 1970s-1980s .

`` some of the investment to boost our productivity , which is actually a global problem , not just a uk problem , is about looking maybe five or 10 years out for a return , and encouraging government to take a lead in doing quite a lot of the r & d that has no specific payback , '' he tells the bbc 's today programme .
`` we just want to encourage a longer term perspective in terms of the r & d investment that is done through the whole economy . ''

documents.title: moving out of britain
text: multiple firms with a base in the uk have already come up with contingency plans in the event that brexit negotiations go sour .

`` a firm i spoke to in belfast last year , because of tariffs and red tape that would result from a 'no-deal brexit ' , they have pulled together plans for moving to france , '' carolyn fairbairn , director general of the cbi told the today programme .
`` it 's that kind of contingency plan that firms are putting together .
that particular firm has not pushed the go button .
`` 10 % have , 25 % will by the end of the year and a further 25 % by the end of march .
that 's 60 % , and that just shows the extent of planning that 's going ahead . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: brexit urgency 'growing by the day '
text: european trade bodies are meeting with theresa may in downing street on monday to discuss brexit .
this follows a letter sent to donald tusk , president of european council , from european business leaders , urging faster progress on brexit talks .

`` this is an important meeting because the urgency that 's shared by businesses across europe is growing by the day , '' carolyn fairbairn , director-general of the cbi tells the bbc 's today programme .
`` this is very much shared by governments , the council and commission in europe all moving quickly because the deadlines around december are very real . ''
she says : `` there is a real recognition that capital markets and the deep concentration of technology and people here does benefit the european union as a whole .
`` the big message today is one of unity - european businesses do have a mutual interest . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: ladder too high for the young
text: it will be interesting to see if philip hammond takes any steps in addressing intergenerational inequality in next week 's budget .
it is a focus of a comment by paul johnson , director of the institute for fiscal studies , in the times on monday and a subject for wake up to money .
mr littlewood says that is all about housing : `` the argument has been around student debt .
people are leaving university , tens of thousands in debt , wages are stagnant , they ca n't get on the housing ladder .
but i think the big , big part of that is the housing ladder .

`` in fact , in terms of student debt , if you compare us to the united states of america , it is not obvious that our students are entering the labour market with colossally worse debt than the americans but young americans can get on the housing ladder far , far faster and that is almost entirely down to a lack of supply in the united kingdom .
`` you do n't need to be a nobel prize winning economist to know that if you limit supply and demand keeps going up the prices shoot up and that is what has happened . ''
author: BBC Radio 5 live

documents.title: if it ai n't broke
text: so what should we expect from chancellor philip hammond 's budget next week ?
do n't bet on any changes to the corporate tax rate .

mark littlewood , director general of the institute of economic affairs , tells wake up to money : `` one of the good things we saw under george osborne 's chancellorship was a long-term plan on tax - to knock 1 % off corporation tax every year . ''
he says : `` the government 's receipts since cutting corporation tax have been healthy .
some people think that 's in part because of the way companies have changed their accounts but it is not obvious that is is a revenue loser to keep cutting corporation tax . ''
author: BBC Radio 5 live

documents.title: no backing down
text: bombardier defiant over us tariffs
from where canada ?
they need to do something about them breaking the sound barrier .
it scares people .
shakes the whole house from what i 'm told .

documents.title: good morning
text: welcome to business live and this penultimate week before the budget on 22 november .
later on monday , the independent shopkeepers who own nisa will vote on a £ 143m takeover by the co-op .
kicking off a busy few days for the housebuilders is taylor wimpey which will provide a trading update at 7.00am .
stay with us for all the breaking business and economics news throughout the day .
